As someone who comes from a military family, John's story is personal to me. My office will always be a helping hand to #IL03 veterans.

If you or a loved one needs assistance receiving lost, misplaced or never received service medals ‚Äî our office is here to help you.

After a local journalist contacted our office about John, our team got right on the case to ensure he finally received the medal he fully deserved. 

Yesterday, I was honored to present John with the Purple Heart he should have received decades ago. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_P2n4ZXEAcnjDn.jpg

A Southwest Side native, John served in the Korean War until he was injured by a misfired Army mortar. 

For decades, he believed he was ineligible for a Purple Heart because he was hit by friendly fire. 

Even after that rule changed in 1999, he still never received it. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_P2nbqWYAMzM7n.jpg

This week, our office helped 94-year-old John Kost finally receive the Purple Heart he had earned seven decades ago for his brave service.

Other provisions eliminate loopholes, promote competition, and fight the exploitation of patients by placing fair checks on insurers, manufacturers, and drug companies. (12/12)

Click here to learn about my plan with @RepSchrader to lower drug costs: https://scottpeters.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/reps-peters-schrader-unveil-plan-to-cut-patients-drug-costs-preserve

Our bill works to lower prices at the pharmacy counter while preserving America‚Äôs unparalleled medical science ecosystem. We want the talent and know-how that has developed therapies and cures and the amazing COVID-19 vaccines to stay on our shores. (11/12)

As price-setting scares off investment, it threatens jobs in American science, especially in my district where the life sciences industry employs about 27k San Diegans. (10/12) https://www.sandiegobusiness.org/research/industry-profiles/life-sciences-2/

If we signal to investors through price setting that they may not be able to recoup their investment not only for their successes, but also their failures, they‚Äôll invest elsewhere & we may well lose our ability to find cures to the toughest and rarest chronic diseases. (9/12)

In 2018 alone, private investment funded $102 billion of US drug development ‚Äì dwarfing the budget of the NIH, and without risk to taxpayers. The cycle of risking private investment in research and development for a return down the line has generated great results. (8/12)

This bill also protects America's ability to find life-saving cures.

The @USCBO found that, accounting for failures, the cost to bring a drug to market could be as high as $2 billion. That‚Äôs for just one drug or treatment. (7/12) https://www.cbo.gov/publication/57126

The Reduced Costs & Continued Cures Act empowers Medicare to negotiate with manufacturers to bring down the cost of expensive treatments when competition fails (i.e. no generic or biosimilar has been marketed & the initial period of exclusivity has expired for a product). (6/12)

Our bill further reduces the cost burden on patients by ensuring that cost-sharing at the pharmacy counter is based on the drug's post-discount price rather than the drug's original list price. (5/12)
https://healthpolicy.usc.edu/research/how-would-sharing-rebates-at-the-point-of-sale-affect-beneficiary-cost-sharing-in-medicare-part-d/

We also set a ‚ú®$50 out-of-pocket monthly maximum for insulin‚ú® under Medicare Part D plans. This could mean savings of $100s per month for seniors who rely on insulin to manage their diabetes but struggle to pay the expensive costs each month. (4/12)

To minimize the impact on seniors with fixed incomes, we've included a 'smoothing' mechanism so that those with expensive annual drug costs can pay their out-of-pocket expenses throughout the year via monthly installments instead of all at once. (3/12) 
https://nationalhealthcouncil.org/blog/blog-updated-smoothing-out-pocket-cap/
